top_comment.text:
How is Delos anchored? Looks like you have a bow anchor out and the stern 
is tied to a mooring buoy. ﻿
top_comment.author: Christopher Young

comments.text:
Yep, +Simon Cadieux is right.  The swell was coming in a different 
direction then the wind so to avoid the "rolly-polly" anchorage we do this 
sometimes to keep the bow into the swell.
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
That's probably for getting the bow in the wave and preventing the boat 
from turning which would be very unconfortable.

comments.text: Hey, John.  Have not heard from you in a while.  Hope all is well.
comments.author: Tom Peranteau

comments.text:
Hi John!  Thanks for watching the videos!  So we use the Go Pro for most 
shots where we're around water or where we think it would be cool to get 
something with the fisheye lense.  It does pretty good as long as there's 
good light.  Our main camera however is a Canon M500 which is pretty 
impressive for the price. 

We're trying to upload Part 2 right now but our internet is too slow :(  
Stay tuned!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.author: SV Delos Crew

captions.text:
After a 700 mile two week sail
from Bundaberg

we arrived in Cairns just in
time to meet Josje at the
airport.
"HIII!!!"
"You look so tan already!"

"We're getting some sun's"
"Yeah.."

"How are you?"
"Good, how are you?"
"Good! HI GUYS!!"

With the Delos crew complete we
lounged at the Cairns Lagoon,
otherwise known as Backpacker
Central.

It was so awesome to have
everyone together again after
being spread across

three continents during the off
season.

Ready for some land adventures
we traded in the dinghy for a
little Hertz rent a car and hit
the road.
We happened across a winery

on our drive north, and with 30
minutes before the hounds were
released we went for it.

and other exotic fruits instead
of grapes.

It was delicious and we bought
a few bottles to take back to
Delos.

"But that's like a dessert you can sell"
"Good stuff!"

Slightly liquored up we headed
for Mossmon gorge

to check out the bush in Far
North Queensland.

This area is really cool.
Massive trees line the
hillsides and the area is full
of creeks.

Never passing up a chance to
swim,

we took advantage of the
refreshing water to cool off
and do a bit of bathing.
"Leaving Cairns!"

"Hiking and wine tasting.."
"Oh yeah!"
♪ It begins at the end ♪

We had a blast in Cairns, but
it was good to be back on the
water and sail as a full crew.

Safely anchored at Fitzroy we
decided to take the good ole'
AB to shore and see if we could
crash the beach resort.

We set up on the beach and
brought out the good stuff.

Nothing beats box wine when
you're on a budget!
♪ drink wine like water ♪

Sunshine, friends, and wine.
What more does one really need?
Ready to be active we decided

to tackle the long trek to the
top of the island.

Nearly a year and a half ago
arriving from the Solomon
Islands,

this light house marked our way
safely through the great
barrier reef and into Cairns.

So much had passed since that
night when Delos slipped
through the pass

at this very spot in the dead
of night.

At one point we were spread
across all corners of the world
to make money to sail again.
And now we were back!

It was great to be sailing
again and working our way north
to more adventures.

We continued our trek to the
very top of the island,

looking forward to a good view
and cool breeze.
"How ya goin?"
"Tired"
(panting)
"OK! Just made it to the top!"

(SIGHS)
(strong wind)
"Pretty * * * *ing good view!"

That night we replenished our
bodies with a chicken parma
feast.

It was a few drinks and then
bed. We were sailing in the
morning!
Up next!

The crew dives at Milln Reef,
gets a new dinghy,

and shops for our 1300 mile
sail to Darwin.
